It's a unique game, something different from the dopamine-optimized high-octane fast action gameplay that has become the standard for "non-cozy" games. Kingdom Come: Deliverance is slow and clunky, but has an incredible charm and large, large focus on the role-playing aspect of the RPG. For me, the game draws many similarities to games like Skyrim, but this game is better in practically every way. Characters in KCD feel very real and the main story is compelling enough to keep me interested. And while the combat in this game is EXTREMELY flawed, it adequately portrays a story in itself as you, playing Henry of Skalitz, go from someone who struggles to take down a single person to a fearsome knight capable of slaying multiple men at once.

The way the combat evolves alongside your knowledge and understanding of how it works is a double-edged sword. The "Master-Parry" system essentially guarantees that you can succeed in any swordfight by playing like a coward and never swinging first. Additionally, because enemies can ALSO master parry you, you're punished for fighting offensively on more skilled enemies, with no course of action to avoid getting hit other than to simply not ever swing first. As you progress through the game, this becomes less of an issue in random encounters due to your overwhelming stat advantage, but more of an issue in late-game quests involving fights with higher-difficulty enemies. Over the course of my playtime, I fell in and out of love with the combat, and recognized how unique and fun it felt to master while also seeing the cracks in the system.

Outside of combat, KCD is extrordinarily slow. You're forced in an animation to pick flowers. You're forced in an animation to open every single door in the entire game. You're forced to stop playing the game constantly in very small but extremely prevalent micro-doses of time. Washing your armor, Waiting for time to pass, Getting in and out of bed, it all takes a small but unnecessary amount of time. This enhances the gritty 1400's medieval RPG aspect of the game to an immense degree, but also comes at the cost of potentially alienating a large audience of people who simply don't have the time or patience to play the game. Combined with the functional but outdated U.I. of the inventory and skills screens, I put down this game in the tutorial area two individual times before I was finally in the right mindset to play it through on my third.

Despite what may seem like me complaining, I think that Kingdom Come: Deliverance is actually a good game. It's unique and interesting, and if you're both a patient person and also looking for a medieval RPG that stays grounded and real, there isn't a better game on the market for you. I'm only that type of person in periodic bursts of time in my life, so I never managed to finish the game. But I do respect it for what it is, and thoroughly enjoyed a lot of the time I spent playing it while I had the right mindset to do so.

Honestly, I didn’t expect to get this hooked. The start was a bit rough — the combat takes time to get used to and the game doesn’t hold your hand — but once it clicks, it’s amazing. Yeah, there are some janky moments here and there, but nothing that ruins the experience. Easily one of the most immersive RPGs I’ve ever played. I seriously can’t wait to jump into Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2.

Playing this game takes me out of this spacetime and puts me in 1403 AD Bohemia as Henry of Skalitz. Riding from village to village, doing quests and fighting Bandits and Cumans (sometimes fleeing for my life) truly makes me believe I am Henry. Can't wait to play KCD 2.

Honestly, when KCD came out, I didn't see anything interesting in it at all.

I ignored this game for a few years... and then one day i decided to give it a try. 
After a few hours of playing, i completely changed my mind. You as a player find your self in an authentic medieval world, and it's not just some fantasy, it's Czech history, with an atmosphere and details that pull you deep in immediately.

You play as Henry, a blacksmith's son, and gradually become entangled in intrigue, war, and personal revenge. The story grabs you because things aren't black and white, your decisions have real consequences, and every choice can change the course of events.

Gameplay is realistic... 

Combat isn't just "swing your sword and you're done" you have to learn to block and use weapons strategically. There is a small details like clothing style for better charm and charisma, force you to think like a 14th century person, which can be frustrating at first but that´s totally adds incredible depth.

Personally, i find the quests a bit confusing at times, sometimes you have to search for clues or figure out exactly what to do next. But at the same time, i appreciate their diversity and freedom, you can often choose a completely different approach and still complete the quest. This feeling of freedom and the ability to do things your own way is rare and fantastic in RPGs.

The graphics and atmosphere are beautiful.

For example the forests, villages, castles, everything have a soul. The sounds and music complement everythink around you well that you can easily forget the outside world. 

Yes, this game have some bugs.. (Emote: vavraNesouhlas) But this experience of this game you won't soon forget.


Verdict: 9/10 – Kingdom Come: Deliverance isn't for everyone, but if you want to really "touch" Czech history, it's worth it.

...but it's also one of the most broken games I have ever played. It seems like every single system is bugged to some extent. I had so many issues while playing. NPCs behaving weirdly, detecting me for no reason, or interrupting me while I talk to someone else, my actions not affecting reputation, quests bugging out and not progressing, and a whole lot of minor glitches like an enemy walking backwards into camp and sitting down backwards on a bench, preventing me from approaching them. These problems affected my gameplay so badly, that half of my playtime was wasted on retracing my steps after something broke.

It's partly my fault because I wanted to play stealthily and as a pacifist and the main story is not made with this in mind. I'm baffled that there is even an achievement for this in the game. Firstly the protagonist is a complete jackass that starts fights for no reason at all, and I as a player have to pay for it, breaking my immersion, but also putting me into situations I have no answer for. Most of the time I simply ran away, because I literally can't fight them, but that broke the quests most of the time.

The best example for this was not in the main story, but in a side-quest where I had to find someone sabotaging something. After I found them I wanted to knock them out and hand them over to the guards. Solid plan right? I found them and saw them literally standing over a dead body. I approached silently and tried to choke them out, and suddenly they start talking to me. WTF?! They then tried to tell me that the body is still alive and I should have a closer look, which ends the conversation. They then back into me BECAUSE I'M STILL BEHIND THEM and draw their weapon. Hello? I'm still here you know? So I just choke them out a second time. Well apparently I shouldn't have done that because now the quest is broken. The quest doesn't progress, the guards are completely braindead and ignore anything I do with the body right in front of them, and I can't interact with anything else. The only thing I CAN do is kill them. Which is actually what the quest expects me to do. So I quite literally can't finish it. I then proceeded to chuck them around and knock them out until they randomly died without it couting as a kill in my statistics for some reason.

Another example, in the main story this time, is when I had to infiltrate a camp and sabotage their equipment. The camp is really linearly designed, there is only a few entryways, everything else has invisible walls. The game forces you to interact with it's disguise mechanic where you can steal armor of a faction and they won't detect you (in theory). So I did that. Nice, a quest where my playstyle works right? Well, no. Anything you do in the camp they notice, but not immediately. You do something and run away and some 30 seconds later some guy randomly approaches you and starts a fight, no matter if you were seen, no matter if you are around, no matter if you are disguised, they just know. I tried for an hour and it simply wouldn't work no matter what I tried.
Ok, let's try a different approach. I will wait till nightfall and sneak into the camp. Splinter Cell style.
Yeah no, even worse. They didn't see me for even a second, but as soon as I do anything, they know I exist, my home address, social security number, current location, Tinder status... it's a joke.

I won't be finishing this game. It's too frustrating. If you're not like me and don't have the stupid idea of doing this as a pacifist, then you'll probably have fun. It's really sad because in itself the stealth system is really well put together, and it's so much fun to break into homes and rob them of everything, especially so because the homes are so varied in layout, but then the quests come around and trash everything. It's even sadder because the story is really good, and the characters are really well written.. :(

Kingdom Come Deliverance is one of those games that sticks with you long after you finish it. At the start you are a nobody who can barely swing a sword, and the game makes you feel that. But that is what makes the whole journey so good. When you actually get better, you know you earned it.
The world feels real. Not fantasy real, but like an actual slice of medieval life. Villages, forests, and towns feel lived in, the NPCs feel like real people, and the attention to detail is insane. The story pulls you in and the quests are way more interesting than your usual RPG stuff. Even the side quests have proper depth.
Combat is tough at first. You will lose fights. You will get smacked around. But once you understand how the system works, it becomes super rewarding. Winning a duel or surviving a messy fight feels amazing because the game never treats you like a superhero.
It is not a fast or flashy game. It takes its time, but if you let yourself get into it, it becomes one of the most immersive RPG experiences out there. If you want a medieval game that actually feels grounded, with a great story, memorable characters, and gameplay that makes you work for your progress, this is 100% worth playing.

[h1] A Master of Character Development [/h1]

I slept of Kingdom Come Deliverance for years, after seeing the success of the 2nd title I figured I would give it a go and start with the first in the series. I have to say I was absolutely blown away with this game. It both realistically and decidedly forces you into the role of a peasant with absolutely no skills and encourages you to develop him along his journey. Henry has to be one of the most well developed characters I have ever seen in a game, and I am thrilled that there is a second title to explore. The game is massive, and there is so much to do. The world design is excellent, the world feels full and dynamic something that newer open world RPGs have failed to do. Graphically, the game doesn't really hold up, it's pretty in some areas, but certainly shows it's age. I found myself having to push past the dated graphics, thankfully the story quickly draws you in. Now the big thing is the combat, something that initially kept me away from the series, it IS hard at first, but you do learn it and it becomes a LOT easier. I definitely recommend reading up on some tips before getting started that way you don't spend hours flapping around if you're a "side quests before the main quest" person like me. Something I found very clever about the combat system is that it does get easier as Henry grows through his journey. With many skills you get to see this really cool gradual progression that adds to the overall sense that Henry is 'growing up.' The game isn't perfect, and at the end simultaneously feels rushed and too long at the same time. I do wish that there were some characters who were more fleshed out or integrated into the main story and not just left behind because you finished their quest. I'm very excited to see how the second game grows from the first, I don't think I have the energy to do a second playthrough of KCD 1. I can already feel that having played this will make KCD II hit a lot harder, I definitely have to encourage folks interested in the series to start with the 1st title and do at least 1 playthrough, it is so worth it.

Underrated to a crazy degree, I prefer it over the sequel personally. It represents the end of Bethesda's monopoly on this style of western RPG, not necessarily containing every single quality of the open world games of BGS and New Vegas, but being similar enough and making up for any comparatively lacking elements with unique strengths of its own. You can't create your own character and completely forge your own path, but the storyline you do participate in is much more finely crafted than that of any BGS game. The open world is a little on the cramped size, but it completely trounces those of Bethesda with its depth of immersive elements and amount/quality of random events to run into. Combat is an utter crapshoot much of the time, but this only serves to further sell the deadly nature of the time period. All of these elements and more combine to create what might just be the greatest interactive coming of age story constructed to date, an area the sequel doesn't excel quite as much in for me with its less consistent tone and comparative lack of focus. Regardless of whether I'm in majority here with this assessment, I do hope the success of this exceptional duology inspires more developers to pursue this sort of immersive, first-person, systems-heavy style of open world RPG. This sort of game design is too promising to be left solely in the hands of a studio as incompetent as BGS.

The story is not anything exceptional by itself. I like it, but it is not a masterpiece on its own. It is pretty standard with themes like revenge, but the other systems such as combat, environment and progression make the story feel far more immersive than it might seem on paper.

One thing this game does extremely well is the sense of progression. I have never played a game where progress feels so natural and rewarding. Even in the late game you are not invincible.

The combat is the most unique part of the game. Some people really dislike it, but personally I think it is one of the main features that defines the game. It is clunky and unpolished, but when it works it is amazing. It is very difficult to make realistic combat feel good in a game, and considering this was their first attempt I think they did a very good job.

If you enjoy history you will appreciate the level of detail and care put into the world. Many of the characters are based on historical figures. Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a great game with plenty of strengths, but also some major weaknesses that drag the overall experience down. The gameplay is unique and fun, offering a grounded medieval RPG feel that you don’t get from many other titles. However, it can also feel clunky at times, especially during combat situations. Certain features — like riding your horse — can feel a bit off or unresponsive.

The game is fun and engaging, but it comes with its share of annoyances due to weird functionality, like not being able to save unless you find a bed or use Saviour Schnapps. The story itself is decent, but it’s dragged out for too long and becomes a slog to get through, with a heavy load of dialogue and cutscenes that can wear you down.

While the game fits the medieval RPG theme extremely well, it often feels more like a RPG/simulation hybrid, which isn’t necessarily bad — but it could definitely benefit from some streamlining or optional toggles for players who don’t want the full grindy, sim-heavy experience. Those aspects can drain the enjoyment for both casual RPG players and veterans alike.

If that were the only issue, I’d give the game a 7/10 — good, with room for improvement. Unfortunately, the experience is also riddled with serious bugs, including near game-breaking ones. Save file issues can occur, and certain choices you make — in dialogue or through actions — can permanently prevent you from progressing. This happened to me personally: because I helped a certain group earlier in the game, my honor level was too high, and when I needed to fight them later, the game marked them as allies. This caused the mission to fail repeatedly due to “too many friendlies dying,” leaving me stuck with no way forward unless I went back to an older save and lost hours of progress.

Bugs like these, combined with the game’s unpolished clunkiness, hold it back significantly despite its potential.

Final Score: 5/10.

A few tips to have a better experience:

1. Take it slow
-You can blitz through the main story and finish everything if you make that your sole focus, but I highly recommend not doing this. There is a ton to do in this game, and its a lot of fun to do. Rebuild Pribyslavitz, level up your horse, participate in the combat tourneys, learn alchemy, finish Teresa's story line, etc. The story does have some breaks in terms of the timeline and you can usually leave the main story whenever and come back later, but some times you can't do so comfortably without messing with the timeline of the story.

2. Don't take the bandit's gear for use. Only sell it
-Bandits periodically appear on the roads between cities and in the wild. Most of the time, their gear is crap, but high level bandits can carry some very strong gear. Taking all their gear can get you kitted out quite fast, but it become super easy to get max level items in the early game. I recommend that you simply sell the gear for the money and upgrade from the armor smiths and the weapon smiths, as well as the hidden treasure chests and quests. This will slow pacing down and always give you new gear to look forward to.

3. Don't use the wiki unless absolutely necessary.
-With the exception of brewing, just explore the game for yourself. You'll have a lot more fun trying to figure stuff out on your own

4. Enable the bow crosshair
-Aiming without it takes a lot of practice and I, personally, really don't care for it much. Just turn it on and it'll be a whole lot better

5. Try out all the weapons
-Yes, the long sword is the most fun and probably the coolest, but it can struggle against armored opponents. Try out the mace or the axe, and the hunting swords can also be pretty fun. Just don't use polearms. Not being able to store them anywhere makes them effectively useless unless you find one lying around.

6. A bit stereotypical, but have fun
-This game is a lot of fun, but its not for everyone. It can be buggy and tedious at times. I greatly enjoyed the game and believe my money was well worth it, but I can also recognize that it has a lot of flaws. Don't want to grind? Then don't. Don't want to do the side quests? Then don't. Don't want to listen to any of this advice? Then don't. For $30, its well worth the price and the enjoyment you can get from it.

What can I say about Kingdom Come Deliverance? TL;DR The game is engaging enough to drag you back in and make gameplay enjoyable, but not riveting enough to eat up your away time thinking about it. I give it a recommend, though I did wait for a sale before purchasing it.

In more detail ,it's a fairly pleasing combination of Mount and Blade meets The Witcher but without the extremes strengths of either. Mount and blade is a far more immersive war sim and The Witcher is a much more compelling RPG.

Regarding difficulty, combat is likely to be difficult for players that aren't accustomed to so much involvement in a fighting game. It will lack the point and shoot of an Elder Scrolls title and may be frustrating to players that want to wander into the game like a god and kill everything they come across, but it's also satisfying as it requires some skill and sense to get it down once the game gets going. The game progression intends for combat to feel like a hard won accomplishment, and outside the scope of a person starting in the societal role your character begins in.

Generally speaking, the non-player characters are well handled and believable. There's a situation involving a specific lady you meet early in the game that was predictable in outcome, but I digress. The voice acting is adequate, though not always stirring, and occasionally suffer from Oblivion-esc "the same voice actor did both voice lines, but the first one was generic, but the second was "in character", so the contrast is odd", but even those situations are easily forgivable.

The main character is handled well, though for lovers of Femshep playing, it's always gonna be Henry, sorry. There's not a lot of modifying you can do for your character, but honestly he's played off well enough to be a satisfying perspective to be. Again, your character isn't a super hero, especially from the beginning, and he has a rather grounded, believable tone to him.

The story arcs are tropey, but reasonably well handled. Many times you can guess how something will turn out, but there's occasionally a surprise.

All things considered, I'd give it an 8.5 out of 10. It's an enjoyable game, and I'm looking forward to seeing what they do with the continued story. It's worth it a regular price, but I'm a budget gamer. 😅 Anything I'm not certain of, I always buy on discount.

KCD is a very flawed game. On a technical level, it feels clunky to play with how stiff the movement can be, the odd topography and vegetation making traversal off the main path feel inconsistent, and with no shortage of bugs on top of everything else. While on the gameplay side, there’s a mix between mechanics that feel as if they were made awkward on purpose for narrative reasons and those that feel either detached from the rest of the mechanics or very underutilized. Some good writing and a strong historical footing do help it somewhat, but probably not enough to make it a valuable experience for most people.

—-------------------------------------------

Starting with the gameplay, the beginning is extremely rough. Being a blacksmith by trade, you obviously start the game without many other skills. Your swordplay is slow and stiff, archery is wildly inaccurate, and just about everything else is barely useful either thanks to the ability itself being worthless or your skills being so low that you need to use the system a lot before it becomes worth using. Even worse, the combat skills are broken up into swords, maces, and axes so even getting good at one will hardly help you with others. From a narrative perspective this makes sense and all. They’re trying to emphasize how out of your league Henry is at the start of the game and build up his abilities in line with his character growth. And while I can’t fault that, it does still make the early game a very annoying experience and I could barely stand the combat until at least 10-20 hours in. But even beyond that point the combat never becomes good and instead feels like an occasional chore rather than a genuine challenge.

Within combat, the gameplay is extremely stiff. Melee revolves around directional inputs which change where you swing your sword and where you defend, plus a few reaction-based elements for a parry or dodge. Because of this, the lock-on is an essential feature of combat since you need one stick to control your movement, strafing while facing the enemy so neither of you can get in a sneaky hit, and the other for looking around. This works fine against a single foe, but against multiple the lock-on becomes a huge disadvantage since it's very sticky to your current target and takes time to switch away, meaning you can see an enemy blow coming but can't block in the right direction or swing at a valuable target because you’re still locked on to somebody else. Meanwhile the directionality of the swings and blocks is stiff and unresponsive, preventing me from doing what I intend even after many hours trying to wrestle the system into submission. Again, this makes some sense from a narrative perspective as you’re not meant to be a killing machine or anything similar, but when I’m struggling even against some basic foes something has clearly gone wrong.

—----------------------------------------------------

Outside of the combat, the rest of the gameplay is also quite rough. There are lots of skills but most of them are so marginal that they barely seem worth including. Herbalism makes you better at picking herbs which are then used to brew potions, but both of these mechanics are extremely slow and the potions aren’t all that helpful anyway. Hunting lets you get more meat and skins from animals, but food and money are both so plentiful that it hardly seems worth it, not to mention what a hassle hunting is in the first place. And some might as well not exist like Drinking, Houndmaster, Unarmed fighting, and a few others. The only abilities outside the combat which felt useful were Speech, Reading (you start off illiterate so reading is actually quite important to learn), and lockpicking/pickpocketing/stealth though the latter few are pretty situational to your playstyle.

—----------------------------------------------------------

The open world looks good at first but ends up feeling quite hollow. Most of your time will be spent in the game’s various towns and cities rather than out in the wilderness since that's where most of the quests are. While there were some attempts to populate the rest of the world with interesting stuff (accidents along the road, buried treasure, random encounters, and occasional bandits) it really isn’t enough to make the roads anything more than an area to pass through rather than anything worth lingering around for. And while there are some abilities that are meant to make the rest of the map more meaningful (like herbalism, hunting, etc) they really don’t do enough to change the fundamental issue that there’s very little benefit for the amount of time you spend there.

It also doesn’t help that anything other than sticking to the main roads is very messy given how stiff the movement often feels. Me and my horse will easily get stuck in some bushes, along a creek, on a fence, or any number of small impediments. You’re unlikely to find much of interest by looking around as all the big secrets are nestled in pretty obscure spots which means trying to explore will just end up with you combing a whole area and maybe not even finding anything as a result. Outside of the first ⅓ of the game I tried to spend as little time outside the cities as I could manage.

—-----------------------------------------------------------

KCD’s strongest aspect is definitely its atmosphere. Both the urban and rural environments do a good job at capturing a specific feel which feels both true to the time but still recognizable. Visually everything is quite good even if there isn’t much variety between buildings. While the scale is obviously off by quite a lot, it's never so absurd as to throw off immersion since you’re not in any of the major parts of the country where this kind of scale would seem outrageous. The focus on realism over gameplay does contribute in this regard, making Henry feel like a part of the world rather than some sort of player-controlled aberration. He learns and improves over the course of the game but never becomes overpowered like you might see from a similar title.

The story also contributes a fair bit to this sense. While the game starts with your home city being razed by a pretty large army, this is much more of a stop along their way to more important areas rather than a meaningful theater in its own right. Your fights are much more restricted to the smaller forces left behind in the area and various bandits & mercenaries who are taking advantage of the conflict for their own ends. The characters are generally good, being minor enough in the grand scheme of things that their actions aren’t a huge force on history but they’re still clearly influenced by events much larger than themselves. Henry is obviously the star here in showing a believable trajectory for his growth over the course of the game but the other major characters manage to fulfill their role quite well, particularly Hans and Radzig.

—-------------------------------------------------------

There are two games with the best open worlds ever made: [b]The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind[/b] and [b]Gothic II[/b].
What makes them so great? Two things: they’re packed with places to explore, and exploration is actually rewarded.

For example, in these games you can step off the main road and stumble upon a smuggler’s cave, an ancestral tomb, or the ruins of an ancient fortress. If you take the time to explore, you’ll always find something interesting — maybe a weapon, some armor, or even a legendary artifact. Who knows?

It’s a pity that the open world in [b]Kingdom Come: Deliverance[/b] lacks these qualities.
Sure, the sheer size of the map is impressive. But what’s the point of having such a huge world if it’s mostly empty or filled with nothing but generic trees and bushes? Why spend ten real-time minutes riding your horse across dull plains, only to encounter a random gang of thugs? The game simply doesn’t reward exploration at all.

I think I know what this game reminds me of. There was a really old RPG for the Amiga called [b]The Faery Tale Adventure[/b], and it had the exact same problem — vast, empty fields with a few scattered enemies.

And with [b]KC:D[/b], it’s not just the open world that feels uninspired — the quests do too. They almost always boil down to “kill some nameless bandits in a random camp,” “bring me ten pieces of meat,” or “steal some random item from a random NPC.” Sure, there are a few exceptions, like the quest where you get drunk with the priest — but even that one stands out only because of the cutscenes, not because of the gameplay itself.

Let’s go back to [b]Morrowind[/b] for a moment. NPCs there were pretty dumb — they’d often run into walls and get stuck — but at least that was back in 2002. In [b]Kingdom Come: Deliverance[/b], NPCs are on about the same level of “intelligence,” if not worse.

First frustration of this game is the combat. It's basically any lore for a FromSoftware game, to which I mean it's ambiguous, requires the player to do considerable digging on their own to understand 10% of it, and you're honestly not going to make sense of it till you watch a YouTube series. Only now am I finally getting comfortable with handling things, but as a new player get ready for misery and suffering. You will lose, over and over, and die, where honestly you may as well have afk when the fight began because you made a mistake by even getting caught into combat. It does come down to considerable understanding of the mechanics and skill, but there's also just flat out % disadvantages you have no idea about that will decide the outcome. Which in of itself wouldn't be the worst, since there is at least some breadth and skill put into the system, leading us to the next thing...

The save system. Unless you set your phone to remind you every half an hour to manually save (which costs a limited early game resource that you realistically will not have any more of for a while), don't even bother playing this. Decided to leave the town? You came across 3 bandits, game over. You will not win as you have no armour or decent weapons (you're also an illiterate child defending yourself with a spoon, considering you haven't improved your combat stats yet). You cannot run away, as they will run you down and kill you as well. And all those dialogues, herb picking, alchemy, reading, etc you've done need to be done again. Trying to simply follow the starting quest line? Whelp you left town to do so, and got ambushed. Alt+F4, it genuinely will be faster. In order to succeed in this game early, you are going to grind tedious actions over and over to just barely have a chance. And if you didn't save in the last 30 minutes, get ready to pick 50 herbs, 1 by 1, with a 5 sec animation per, all over again. Now that this game has trained me through paranoia and raised blood pressure, I don't lose much progress when things inevitably go wrong, but for a new player I hope you enjoy being bored doing the same thing you just did for the past 2 hours again, and you paid money for this experience.

You can't change gamma or contrast. I get immersion, but this is the most basic of settings. Might as well have forced me to not be able to adjust the volume, or looks sensitivity. It's so weird not to include this, and things will get so pitch black that your monitor may as well have been off.

Your dog has a collision box. That in of itself is fine, except your dog AI will make it push you, effectively pushing you out from stealth or off a cliff (both happened). Furthermore, you can't push him. So get ready for an annoying burden that will stop you from picking flowers, get you killed/detected, and trap you in buildings.

No indicator for timed quests. [h3] Gameplay [/h3]
Unfortunately, gameplay is not better. “Random” guard searches are annoying, magically they know if you have stolen something. I was even searched at the last quest. Weirdly, they did not care if something breaks the immersion. Another negative thing was the save system: Year 2018 and the developers thought limited save system is a good choice at an RPG. Since that wasn’t enough to make the game annoying, they decided to put timed quests. I can hear you saying “What is wrong with that system? After fighting many enemies with this annoying combat system, you may think that you can get a good level-up, perks, skills etc. Guess what? Level-ups are the worst level-ups I’ve ever seen. First of all, [spoiler] one of the last quests, you get captured and the reason for this is a noble that has seen you less than 5 minutes at the start of the game (near a year ago) and recognizing you, while you are wearing a full suit of knight armour. I really liked playing this game but I cannot in good conscience recommend it due to crashing, bugs/jank and general lack of optimization. If you still want to experience KCD, maybe you are like me and started playing this before going into the 2nd, I’d suggest turning some graphic options down (the game will look the same) and keep your focus almost purely on the main quest and DLC’s.

My whole playtime of 234h was on hardcore where I had about 80% of the whole map FULLY explored and after finishing the game and looking up a quest list, I saw that I had managed to complete all but one of a side mission which can be missed if you do another minor quest first – the quest was apparently named “Hare Hunt” and I could see the marker on the map but the NPC didn’t have new dialogue about it and after finishing that minor quest the NPC disappeared anyway, which was fine as it is part of how this game handles choice and consequence. I can confidently say that I experienced pretty much everything that this game can offer unless I myself am to impose extra roleplaying handicaps in a future playthrough like not looting dead bodies or not killing anyone (there’s an achievement about it).

So look, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is an open world sandbox the likes of Bethesda’s Oblivion that focuses a lot on historical accuracy (instead of magic and fantasy e.t.c.) with the immersion and slow meticulousness that you can encounter is the likes of Red Dead Redemption 2. One can say the I’m being unfair here as both these games are giants in their own right, but to me this is a compliment. KCD was made with a certain vision in mind and when it manages to fire with all its cylinders it definitely approaches that bar that could make it exceptional. The OST, the handcrafted cities, the amazing voice acting and memorable cast all serve to give you this curated impression of medieval Bohemia and the care that was put into it shows - KCD is punching above its weight and most of the time it succeeds. You will be fully immersed with its systems playing as Henry, a young boy with no prior experience whatsoever in trying to survive this unforgiving world while also navigating a revenge story that by the end of it you will truly feel a sense of accomplishment as your character will turn from an apprentice blacksmith to a veteran/soldier as he rides into the sunset to his next adventure (presumably the second game).

That impression is so strong that I feel like for most people is enough to wave away most of this game’s faults but for me the opposite happened, in that those issues took away from the experience.

You see you are given this big map to explore but outside the major settlements you will find two things: jack and sh*t. All these lush green forests and rolling hills certainly serve as a pretty good back drop (or a place to frequently get lost in) but there’s mostly nothing there to explore. The map is dotted with POIs that have some short of environmental story telling – like a carriage filled with arrows and blood or a hut with a book about skinning and a tub with corpse in it – but that is not enough for a map as big as KCD’s. Also there is not a hint of danger in exploring these areas as most bandits can be encountered in respawning camps or in road encounters, there are no aggressive wild animals or other dangers here other than about a billion rabbits and the occasional fleeing deer or boar. That map size also works as a detriment as quest givers will frequently ask you to zip around the other settlements to progress but by the 50h mark you will probably have cycled through all the random encounters and so you will just ride past them as there is no reason to stop. Maybe this is a hardcore mode issue where it disallows fast travel but I figured if I wasn’t playing that mode, after a point I’d fast travel so I wouldn’t even see the awesome vistas anyway. That emptiness is also felt in one of the smaller settlements (Samopesh) as it doesn’t even have a reason to go there other than talking to the blacksmith to send you to a DLC quest.

Since I mentioned quests, most of the main adventure is amazing. You can see a lot  of the budget was spent here as there’s endless voice acting and even mocaped scenes to complement it. The adventure path starts by teaching you the game mechanics and then offers interesting scenarios to play in – some missions are pure investigations but there’s nothing really stopping you from changing your approach, either by stealth or combat. Another important element is that the game recognizes your choices and I just loved how the dialogue is affected by your speech skill and the way you dress and look. It adds to the roleplay element that a sandbox such as this needs. It is outside the main story where the façade crumbles as most quests are fetch this or bring 100 meat there which exacerbates the disappointment felt by the emptiness of an admittedly pretty to look landscape.

Perks and Combat is another thing worth to mention, specifically melee combat with the closest system to this being Ubisoft’s For Honor (really cool game btw) but in first person. The issue is that the camera janks out if you try to engage in more than 3 enemies and if you get surrounded you will die regardless of your gear. Personally I enjoyed it as it was sensical to never engage more than 2 enemies at once (I’m an inexperienced peasant story wise after all) and it also made me scout more to see which enemy is more armored so that I change my approach by stealth, use poison and bow and generally engage the whole skill system in creative ways. I suspect most people don’t like it due to camera issues that ensue when you try to brute force your way through but even those can be surpassed with the use of alchemy and steroids by one hitting anyone but the most heavily armored opponents. When it comes to perks, the skill system is a missed opportunity to add more creativity to the game as half of them are completely useless (like herbalism) or absolutely essential (maintenance/sneak/alchemy). Fortunately it is easy to differentiate between the two.

Anyways, writing all of the above made me realize that for the most part KCD is a sold 6/10 (maybe even 7/10) game. It struggles a bit but for the most part it does what is wants to do and is unapologetic about it which I respect. The game does the Bethesda thing where it offers something awesome enough to make you ignore the jank and bugs like flickering smokefires or T-posing enemies. So I will also be unapologetic here as I am incapable of ignoring the frequent stuttering (I also put the game on a 7800x3d/9070xt and the stuttering persists), the slowdown after an hour of playtime (RAM issue?) or the game crashing randomly. Or not so randomly as I initially thought as it became more frequent during the last sequences of the adventure. Heck, while I was finishing the game in the last mocaped cutscene where the hero has an emotional dream sequence with his father I got subtitles from a DLC quest scene and as that ended and I was left in the major hub area, went on my horse and crashed, so I had to replay the last sequence. What a cherry to put on top.
